fields.value: Replication Data for: The Dynamics of Partisan Identification when Party Brands Change: The Case of the Workers Party in Brazil

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Replications materials for "The Dynamics of Partisan Identification when Party Brands Change: The Case of the Workers Party in Brazil" 
"Two-City, Six-Wave Panel Survey, Brazil" (2002, 2004, 2006). Sample: Representative samples of (1) Caxias do Sul, Rio Grande do Sul and (2) Juiz de Fora, Minas Gerais. Topic areas: Neighborhood quality of life, worst problems, economic assessments, political participation, media and campaign attention, civil society and neighborhood involvement, political discussion frequency, trust in government and institutions, vote choice, core values, interpersonal persuasion, feeling thermometers of groups and politicians, party identification, ideology, candidate trait assessments, candidate ideological and issues placement, issues self-placement, evaluation of Lula's government, political knowledge, discussant name generator. Sample size: About 25,000 interviews. Special features: Interviews with named political discussants, 100 interviews per neighborhood.

publicationCitation.value: Andy Baker, Barry Ames, and Lucio R. Renno (2006). "Social Context and Campaign Volatility in New Democracies: Networks and Neighborhoods in Brazil's 2002 Elections." American Journal of Political Science 50(2): 382-99.

fields.value:
Used in the following:

Barry Ames and Amy Erica Smith (2010). "Knowing Left from Right: Ideological Identification in Brazil, 2002-2006." Journal of Politics in Latin America 2(3): 3-38.

Barry Ames and Lucio R. Renno (2010). "Participatory Budgeting, Discussion Networks, and Political Information in Two Brazilian Cities." In Michael Wolf, Ken'ichi Ikeda, and Laura Morales (eds.), Political Discussion in Modern Democracies: A Comparative Perspective. London: Routledge Press.

Barry Ames, Andy Baker, Lucio R. Renno (2008). "Split-Ticket Voting as the Rule: Voters and Permanent Divided Government in Brazil." Electoral Studies 28:8-20.

Barry Ames, Andy Baker, and Lucio R. Renno (2008). "The 'Quality' of Elections in Brazil: Policy, Performance, Pageantry, or Pork?" In Timothy J. Power and Peter R. Kingstone (eds.), Democratic Brazil Revisited. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press.

Andy Baker, Barry Ames, and Lucio R. Renno (2006). "Social Context and Campaign Volatility in New Democracies: Networks and Neighborhoods in Brazil's 2002 Elections." American Journal of Political Science 50(2): 382-99.
